Every individual shot: Numbers are used to indicate direction and depth
including serves: while letters are used to specific shot types (e.g. "f" stands for "forehand") and error types ("n" stands for "net").

Every individual shot: A few symbols are used for other purposes
including serves: such as types of errors (e.g. "@" means "unforced error" and "+" indicates an approach shot).

Every individual shot: If the first serve goes in
including serves: the entire point is coded in the "1st" cell.

Every individual shot: If the first serve goes out
including serves: only the first serve (its direction and error type) is entered in the "1st" cell.  Then the 2nd serve and rally are entered in the "2nd" cell.

Every individual shot: See the two example points shown below.  In the first point
including serves: the first serve lands in ("6") and the ensuing rally ("f27b1*") is entered immediately after.
the first serve is a fault ("5d").  The second serve lands in ("4") and the rally ("s39b3b1w@") is entered along with it in the "2nd" column.

Every individual shot: Keep reading to learn what all these numbers
including serves: letters
and symbols actually mean!

including serves: use a number to indicate direction:
5 = body
and 6 = down the T. (These numbers are the same in both the ad and deuce courts.)

Every individual shot: The number 0 (zero) can be used if you don't know the direction.
If the serve is a fault
including serves: a lowercase letter to indicate the type of fault. There are five types of faults:

Every individual shot: n = net (anything that goes into the net
including serves: including net cords that are not lets)

Every individual shot: You may also use the letter 'e' to designate an unknown type of fault (for instance
including serves: if you didn't see it
or the TV camera cut away).

Every individual shot: In rare cases when players shank a serve
including serves: use "!" to indicate a shank
rather than the letter to indicate the type of error.

Every individual shot: When the server commits a time violation and loses his first serve
including serves: the code is 'V' (uppercase).
while this is not necessary
you may record let serves.  The letter for this is "c" and it can be repeated as many times as there are lets.

Every individual shot: 6 = a serve down the T that lands in the box.
4 = a wide serve that lands in the box
6x = a serve down the T that is both wide and deep.
5d = a body serve that lands deep

including serves: followed by a wide serve that is out
but you don't know in which direction.

Every individual shot: There is also an optional code ("+") to indicate serve-and-volley attempts.  This can be used whether or not the serve goes in.

including serves: a serve-and-volley attempt on which a wide serve lands deep would be coded as "4+w".
start with the direction and the plus sign
then follow with the rally code

Every individual shot: There are four categories for points that never progress past the serve:
Aces. Add a * to the serve notation.  For instance
including serves: "5*" denotes a body serve ace.
only use a #.  So "6#" is a serve down the T that the other player touches but cannot return.  (More on this in a moment.)

Every individual shot: Forced errors.  Code the return as shown below (in 'Rally Sequence') along with the forced error notation ('#').   Example: 6f#
Unforced errors: Code the return as shown below
including serves: along with the unforced error notation ('@').  Example: 6f2d@
"unreturnables" are points where the returner fails to get a full racquet on the ball (including shanks)
fails to get the return all the way to the net

Every individual shot: All other returns are forced or unforced errors.
Differentiating between forced and unforced errors on the service return will always be a prickly subject.

including serves: first-serve return errors are usually forced
and second-serve return errors are often unforced.

including serves: especially in the men's game
many second-serve return errors are forced.

Every individual shot: Each shot after the serve (with the exception of service returns and point-ending "forced" errors--more on that in a minute) requires two characters:
a letter to indicate the type of shot and a number for the direction.
Here are the letters to indicate shot types.  Note that for most types of shots
including serves: there are different letter codes for the forehand and backhand sides.
chips
etc.)

including serves: chips
etc.)

including serves: but not drop shots)
but not drop shots)

Every individual shot: (see below for an optional additional code to indicate a stop volley/drop volley)

including serves: including behind-the-back
between-the-legs

Every individual shot: Here are the numbers to indicate direction:
1 = to a right-hander's forehand side / left-hander's backhand side
2 = down the middle of the court
3 = to a right-hander's backhand side / left-hander's forehand side
Down the middle represents a little more than one third of the court.  While we shouldn't worry about excessive precision
it may be helpful to think of "2" as representing the middle 40% of the court
including serves: while 1 and 3 each represent an outer 30%.

Every individual shot: It may be easier to think of a "down the middle" shot as a typical rallying shot
including serves: even though it may require the other player to move a step or two in either direction.
shot direction should indicate the part of the court where the shot crossed (or would have crossed) the opponent's baseline. For instance
if player A hits

Every individual shot: a wide serve in the deuce court and player B hits a crosscourt return
including serves: the ball might bounce in the middle of the court
but cross the baseline in the corner. In a case

including serves: the direction is 1 (to a right-hander's forehand)
not a 2 (down the middle).

including serves: you can also use the number zero (0) to indicate unknown direction.
and when you first start charting matches
I recommend you stick with the shot-type codes.

including serves: work on adding the shot direction
as it opens up a much wider range of analysis.

Every individual shot: f1 = forehand to a (righty's) forehand side; this is the typical crosscourt forehand
s2 = backhand slice down the middle
u3 = forehand drop shot to a (righty) opponent's backhand side
b3s3b1f1v2 = (assuming both players are righties) backhand crosscourt
including serves: backhand slice crosscourt
backhand down the line

including serves: backhand
half-volley
column4: all without shot direction specified.  As noted

Every individual shot: Winners: Code the rally as shown above
including serves: and add a * (star/asterisk) to indicate a winner.

Every individual shot: example: f3* = forehand winner down the line
Errors: Code the rally as shown above
including serves: *including* the shot that the loser tried to make.

Every individual shot: Add one of the error types (same as those for serves: n = net
including serves: w = wide
d = deep
column6: e = unknown) to the end of the final shot.

including serves: add one of these two characters at the end: @ = unforced error
and # = forced error.

Every individual shot: In the case of a rally-ending error
including serves: you can use up to four keystrokes to describe the error shot:

Every individual shot: shot-type (e.g. 'f') / direction (e.g. '1') / error type (e.g. 'n') / forced or unforced (e.g. '#')

including serves: shot-type
error type
column4: and the unforced symbol ("@") are required; direction (as on other shots after the serve) is optional.

including serves: only shot-type and the forced error symbol ("#") are required.  For example
"b#" is acceptable.  If you wish to add more information (e.g. "b3d#")

Every individual shot: Example: f2f1f1v2n@ = forehand down the middle
including serves: forehand crosscourt
forehand crosscourt
column4: volley down the middle into the net (unforced error).

Every individual shot: Remember that the rally shot sequence is entered in the same cell as the serve that landed in
including serves: so the full entry will look like this:
followed by the rally described above.
so when service returns are in
we add one additional character to indicate depth.

Every individual shot: 7 = within the service boxes. 8 = behind the service line
including serves: but closer to the service line than the baseline.  9 = closer to the baseline than the service line.
service returns require three keystrokes: (1) the type of shot
(2) the direction of the shot
column4: and (3) the depth of the shot.

Every individual shot: Example: f37 = forehand service return to a (righty) opponent's backhand side that lands in front of the service line.
Be careful not to stop and think about this one--the rally will pass you by!  You can always use 0 (zero) for unknown depth or omit a number for depth altogether.

including serves: ETC
the shot codes indicate court position.  If a player must return a drop shot
or hits a volley

Every individual shot: he or she probably came to the net.  If not
including serves: probably not. However
we may want to be more precise.

Every individual shot: Approach shots: To indicate that a shot was an approach shot
including serves: add a plus sign ("+") immediately after the shot code.  For instance
"b+2" is a backhand approach down the middle.

Every individual shot: This not only helps us identify net approaches
including serves: but it also allows us to identify passing shots and passing shot attempts.
the plus sign also indicates serve-and-volley attempts
so for instance
column4: "4+b27v1*" is a point in which the serve was wide
column5: the server followed it into the net

including serves: and the server finished the point with a volley winner.
half-volleys
swinging volleys
column4: and smashes are assumed to have taken place at the net.  Groundstrokes

Every individual shot: assumed to be baseline shots. Use "-" and "=" immediately after the shot code to indicate otherwise.  "-" means that a shot took place at the net
including serves: and "=" that it took place at the baseline.

Every individual shot: Examples: "f-1" = forehand to a (righty) opponent's forehand that took place near the net; "o=2" is a smash down the middle
including serves: hit from near the baseline .

Every individual shot: Net cords: A semi-colon can be added to any shot to indicate that it clipped the net cord.  For example
including serves: "f;1*" is a forehand winner to a (righty's) forehand side that hit the net cord.

Every individual shot: Stop volleys/drop volleys: If a volley is hit so that it drops close to the net (like a drop shot)
including serves: use the additional code "^". For instance
"z^2*" is a backhand ("z") stop volley ("^") down the middle ("2") winner ("*").

Every individual shot: As with the other optional parts of this system
including serves: your chart can be analyzed without the use of these four codes.  Court position is great to have
but it's the lowest priority of anything discussed up to this point.

Every individual shot: If for some reason you miss a point or two
including serves: that's ok.  Entering 'S' in the 1st serve column will give that point to the server; 'R' gives the point to the returner.

Every individual shot: If you miss several points and are unsure of the sequence … go ahead and guess.  Add a note in column P to acknowledge the missing information.
One uncommon event of importance is the point penalty.  If
including serves: for whatever reason
a point penalty is levied on either player
column4: use a single character code in the cell for first serve.

Every individual shot: P = point penalty against the server
including serves: and Q = point penalty against the returner.
this system ignores challenges and other overrules.  If a point is replayed from the beginning
simply delete the uncounted point and start over.

Every individual shot: If a challenge affects the result of a point
including serves: adjust what you've recorded to reflect the result of the challenge.

Every individual shot: Exception: When a player stops play to challenge or check a mark
including serves: there are two possibilities:
she challenges and the ball was out--code the shot as you otherwise would
as a forced or unforced error.

including serves: if she is wrong
use the code 'C' to indicate the incorrect decision to stop the rally. For instance:

including serves: backhand deep up the middle
play stopped for a challenge [which proved incorrect]"

including serves: there is a 'Notes' column available for your use.  For now
that's a catchall for everything that doesn't fit elsewhere.

including serves: medical timeouts
rain delays
column5: time violation warnings--anything you think is worthy of mention

including serves: but please avoid using commas in this column.
if something happens between points (say
a medical time out
column4: which follows the end of a game)
column5: record it in the notes column of the *preceding* point.
